addressleaf.section:
To my vearie lovinge frend M
r
Bodeleie Esq
r
, Counsello
r
for hir Ma
tie
in the Counsell of Estate in the lowe Cuntries.

section.hand:
From my L. T
re
r Au
g
3 1594

deletion.hand:
From my L. T
re
r Au
g
3
1594

page.lettertext:
fol.81r
S
r
. uppo
n
the fyrst daie of this moneth at one
instant I received three letters from yowe, 2 of the xx
th
of the last moneth, and the 3
d
of the xxvij
th
, by both the
former it appeareth that uppon the receipt of my letters of the
vij
th
of Julie declaringe hir
Ma
ties
purpose to reskewe
Brest
and request to have their assistance by Sea, yowe had
conference w
th
the
States
abowt the same, in whome yowe
found good disposic
o
n to assist hir Ma
tie
in that Enterprise
w
th
nine or tenne shippes: But yet bicawse yowe weare
not hable to declare unto them the particularities of hir
Ma
ties
resoluc
o
n for the time, and the Rendez vous, neither w
th
the number of hir Ma
ties
shippes, soldiers, munic
o
n & powder
theie cowld not make present determinac
o
n w
th
yowe, &
yet nevertheles it appeareth by yo
r
second letter that
Mons
r
Caron
had advertised the States perticulerlie of hir Ma
ties
purpose, as the same was determined in my howse the xv
th
of the last moneth and confering w
th
yowe theareuppon
yowe alledged that yowe had not understood the particuler
pointes theareof, and so it semeth by yo
r
writinge, that for
lacke of yo
r
Informac
o
n the matter was at a staie, althowgh
it might appeare well unto yowe by their owne report that
hir Ma
ties
demaund was to have nine or tenne shippes for
tenne monethes, whearein theie fownde noe difficultie to yelde
unto the Quene, nor to the provision of 20000
wzt
of
powder: and yet theie cowld not well conceive what was
ment by a request of two monethes victuels for 2000
me
n
: theie also semed to finde lack in that there was noe
mentio
n
made of munic
o
n, nor of greater quantetie of powder
for the recoverie of the fort of Brest. And by yo
r
letter of
e
28 yt semeth that uppo
n
a letter written by Mons
r
de Caron unto
them the verye xv
th
daie of Julie, that he was countermaunded the
same daie, by all w
ch
uncertainties it hath fallen owt verye
unluckelie that thes preparacons of the States have honge in suspence
and cannot be executed so sone as the time requireth. But
for clearing of all thes former scruples, yowe shall understand
that the verie xv
th
of Julye Mons
r
Caron was directed not onely
what to demaund, of the States, but at what time the same was
required, and what weare the forces then determined by hir Ma
ty
fol.81v
And thowgh it was trewe that the same daie he was written
unto by my
sonne
uppon the Quenes Commaundement, that he should
staie the stending awaie of his l
re
s for the present untill he
might be newlie spoken w
th
all, w
ch
was ment to be the next
daie, and having received that Countermande, he made awnswere
presentlie that he had alreadie sent awaie his l
re
s to the States
agreable to the motions made to him the said xv
th
, wherewith
hir Ma
tie
beinge made acquainted, she was verey well satisfied,
and allowed of his dilligence, and so untill the verye time of the
receipt of thes yo
r
latter letters wee weare in opinion & expectat
o
n
to have held of thes assistances of the States Ships, and other their
provisions to have been at
Portesmowth,
before the fift of this p
nt
moneth. And nowe to explane the demaundes as theye weare made
It is trewe [theire] weare demaunded xij shippes at the least
and victuels for 2000 men that might serve by land for 2 monethes
and as I thinke but 20000
wzt
of powder, w
th
owt anie
wordes of munic
o
n: But nowe to reduce o
r
demaundes to more
certaintie, hir Ma
tie
can be contented w
th
tenne shippes, if
otherwise the States shall not yeld to xij: and for the vic-
tuells, consideringe that w
ch
is alledged by yo
w
of the darthe of
victuells theare, and the cheapenes heare, that demaund may
be forborne, althowgh at this p
nt
by the unseasonablenes of the
yeare, I thinke the darthe of victuels is more heare then
theare, considering the provision of Corne that readelye is to be
had owt of the East Cuntries into thes / As for the small qauntety
of powder demaunded; I thinke the same was mistaken in writinge
for indeade 20000
wzt
of powder is little more then 8 last
,
so as it is nowe rather, required to have threescoare thowsand
weight, w
ch
is not thirtie lastes, and yet if xxx
ty
lastes maye
be had, It shall well content hir Ma
tie
, and so I hope theye
will yeld theareunto, and if it shall be more, it shall be the
more thankefull./ At this time wee ha ve had speeche w
th
Mons
r
Caron declaringe to him the uncertainties gathered by yo
r
letter, wheareunto for o
r
better satisfacc
o
n, he sheweth us letters
written to him from the haghe the 29 of Julye, wheareby in expresse
wordes theie write that theie are readie to send awaie theire
assistance, makinge noe mention of anie dowbt or delaie thearein,
and yet nevertheles he is directed to write back againe thither w
th
all speed to hasten the same, by whome I doe send thes my letters to
yowe at this time.
From the Cort this third of Au
g
1594.
Yo
r
very loving frend
W Burghley
We ar certenly adv
r
tised
t
Laon
is rendred to
e
K.
and
e DD de ma
y
and
armale
ar
chased owt of
Amy
e
s
